results.title: Bridging the centuries
results.creator_credit: Royal Doulton, World Wide and John Patterson Reid
results.brief_description: Traces the history of pottery making in Britain from neolithic times to the present day. Examples of rare English pottery and china from different centuries are shown. Illustrates the influence of Chinese work on the development of English bone china. Describes the evolution of English translucent china particularly for tableware.

results.title: Bridget Riley
results.creator_credit: Balfour Films, Arts Council of Great Britain and David Thompson
results.brief_description: A profile of artist, Bridget Riley. Explores the inspirations she draws from the visual experiences in nature and follows her into her studio where she organises and activates her paintings. Credits include A.A. Englander (photographer) and Roy Ayton (editor).

results.title: Bridget Jones's diary [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Little Bird Ltd, Studio Canal, Working Title Films, Debra Hayward, Liza Chasin and Sharon Maguire
results.brief_description: Bridget Jones (Renee Zellweger) is 32, single, smokes too much, drinks too much, and says what is on her mind. After another disastrous New Years Eve, Bridget makes a resolution to keep a diary, lose weight, cut down on her smoking and drinking, and above all, find herself the perfect man. Her mother tries to assist her in her search for a man, setting her up with Mark Darcy (Colin Firth, in a role comparable to his performance as Mr. Darcy in ‘Pride and Prejudice’), the son of an old family friend. Unfortunately, the first man to notice the new Bridget is her boss, Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), a chauvinistic womaniser with whom she starts a love affair, despite her attraction to Mark. Bridget’s confusion over her attraction to Mark, her relationship with Daniel, is complicated by her meddling and slightly eccentric friends, and the breakdown of her parent’s relationship. Based on the novel by Helen Fielding. Cast also includes Gemma Jones, Celia Imrie, Hugh Grant and Jim Broadbent.

results.title: Bridges in Holland
results.creator_credit: Bert Haanstra Film Productions, Bert Haanstra and Rolf Orthel
results.brief_description: A tribute to Holland’s bridge builders; a beautifully photographed study of the texture and structure of bridges to present a view of Holland in all seasons in all parts. The assembly of shots of bridges from opening ceremonies to demolition tell their own story without commentary. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Bridges
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and David Hughes
results.brief_description: A simply stated stimulus film on bridges. Shows children making bridges, asking questions and talking about bridges. Shots of historic bridges and bridges of Melbourne are interspersed throughout. Suitable for primary years prep-6.

results.title: Bridge to space
results.creator_credit: Seneca Productions, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Charles R. Trieschman and Robert Gaffney
results.brief_description: A bus tour visits the Cape Kennedy Moonport of Project Apollo, recording the impressive sights of the Moonport, of Project A, the Saturn Rockets, the launching pads and control facilities. The tour conductor gives details of the sights.

results.title: Bridge over the Bosporus
results.creator_credit: Turner Film Productions and Michael Bennett
results.brief_description: A record of the building of the bridge across the Bosporus which divides the city of Istanbul. The bridge was opened in October 1973. Narrated by John Carson.

results.title: Bridge over Myall Creek (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Samantha Butler, Brigid Donovan, Vanessa Gorman, Helen Gasswill, John Millard, Wendy Page, Margaret Parker and Caitlin Shea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Caroline Jones introduces this episode of “Australian story” which looks at personal reconciliation in action as demonstrated by the relationship between Sue Blacklock and Beulah Adams, descendants of victim and perpetrator in the 1838 Myall Creek massacre. Researching into her family history, Beulah Adams discovered her great uncle was one of the perpetrators in a massacre that saw 28 Aborigines killed. Beulah talks candidly about her reaction to the news, and her experience at meeting Sue Blacklock, descendant of one of the two survivors at a conference on reconciliation convened by Reverend John Brown. Another descendant of the perpetrators, Des Blake, talks about his experience at attending the memorial’s opening at Myall Creek in 2002, and how the experience has changed his life since then.

results.title: Brideshead revisited. Pt. 1 [episodes 1-5]
results.creator_credit: Granada International Productions, Derek Granger and Charles Sturridge
results.brief_description: This tape comprises of episodes one to five - the first half of the magnificent series set during World War II. It is dawn on a cold winter’s morning in 1943. Charles Ryder, painter turned army captain, in the twilight of World War II has marched most of the night and camped with his platoon at their secret destination. On waking, he is amazed to find he is at the rear of Brideshead Castle where he spent many years of enchantment and grief in his youth, and which, years ago he had left vowing never to return. Now here he was again, cold and with memories flooding over him like storm-surf on the shore. He was back. Brideshead revisited had begun. Cast includes Jeremy Irons, Anthony Andrews, Diana Quick, Laurence Olivier, Claire Bloom and John Gielgud. Adapted from the novel by Evelyn Waugh.

results.title: Brideshead revisited. Episodes 10 & 11
results.brief_description: Julia’s husband reluctantly agrees to a divorce in order that she can marry Charles. Lord Marchmain returns to Brideshead to die, and is horrified at his eldest son’s choice of wife, whom he describes as vulgar and unsuitable as mistress of Brideshead Castle. Finally, Julia’s Catholic beliefs weigh heavily upon her and she declares she cannot marry Charles. It is not until many years later that Charles learns that Lord Marchmain left Brideshead to Julia…and as his memory dissolves, Charles Ryder returns to 1943, to Brideshead Castle, which is now a bleak military encampment. Rated: PG
